Record.Value: In this lesson, we will bring light to the world in the form of electricity.
Welcome back Cadet, Your first task will be to clean up some old burnt out wires. Use the {THING:ItemWireCutters} from your toolbelt to remove them.

Cadet, now that you have a base platform and a few machines in place, you will need to provide them with power. Lest’s start with the {THING:StructureSolidFuelGenerator}. The solid fuel generator is great for emergency power or for early bases that don’t have much energy storage during the night. It's downfall is that it requires solid fuel to work.
Great work, Cadet! Our next task is to set up a {THING:StructureSolarPanel}. This will provide renewable energy for the base without requiring fuel. However, it will only work during the day.

Kits can be used to build different structures and variants. To build this solar panel, you’ll need to swap to the correct variant using the scroll wheel. With the solar panel selected, match the cursor shapes with the highlighted spot. Remember to use {KEY:QuantityModifier} to rotate the object to the correct position.
Like the {THING:StructureAutolathe}, the solar panel also requires an extra step to construct.
Place the {THING:ItemGlassSheets} on the solar panel.

Now we need to connect our equipment together using wires. On Earth, normal wires will do. However, atomic oxygen and solar radiation degrades many substances exposed to space. Hence, we’ve engineered a special type of cable capable of withstanding space environments. It can carry both data and power, allowing you to control machines from a control panel. This will be covered later.
In your {SLOT:Belt}, you will find the {THING:ItemCableCoil}, place the cables in the highlighted area. Remember to use the scroll wheel to select the correct wire and use the {KEY:QuantityModifier} key to rotate to match the placement
Extend the wires to the main platform.

In our next step we need to place a {THING:ItemAreaPowerControl}. Power controllers are used to control the flow of power and prevent cables from burning out they also provide a small amount of intermediate power supply if the generators are offline.
Secondly, we need to add a {THING:ItemBatteryCharger} to charge our depleted batteries. We want to put this in front of our {THING:ItemAreaPowerControl} so that any battery charging won’t drain the battery in the {THING:ItemAreaPowerControl}.
Place the {THING:ItemAreaPowerControl} in the highlighted spot.
place the {THING:ItemBatteryCharger} in the highlighted spot.
Wire the rest of the components up to our machines.

To make the power controller work we need to open the cover and insert a battery then flip the breaker switch to allow electricity and data to pass-through. Its usually recommended to use a large battery to ensure long-lasting power in the event of an outage although a small battery could be used too.
Flip the breaker to the “On” position on the {THING:StructureAreaPowerControl}.
